title: 111_hr2722
content: The Act is titled the "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" and it authorizes the establishment of corporations for veterans' research and education. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" authorizes the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations to facilitate research and education at multiple medical centers. The board of directors of these corporations must include officials from each Department medical center involved. The "Veterans Nonprofit Research and Education Corporations Enhancement Act of 2009" allows for the creation of multi-medical center research corporations to oversee research and education activities at various Department medical centers. These corporations can manage finances related to research and education conducted at the involved medical centers, with approval from the board of directors. The Act allows for the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations to oversee research and education activities at Department medical centers. These corporations must comply with state nonprofit corporation laws and federal laws, and facilitate research activities. The Act allows for the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations to oversee research and education activities at Department medical centers. These corporations must comply with state nonprofit corporation laws and federal laws, and facilitate research activities. The corporations shall be established in accordance with state nonprofit corporation laws and are required to comply only with federal laws and regulations. The Act allows for the establishment of multi-medical center research corporations to oversee research and education activities at Department medical centers. These corporations must comply with state nonprofit corporation laws and federal laws, regulations, and executive orders. They are not owned or controlled by the United States or considered an agency or instrumentality of the United States. Additionally, there is a reinstatement requirement for 501(c)(3) status of corporations exempt from taxation under section 501(c)(3) of the title. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF PURPOSES OF CORPORATIONS. The amendment clarifies the purposes of corporations established under title 38, United States Code, to provide funding for approved research and education at Department medical centers and facilitate related functions. It also modifies the defined term relating to education and training. The amendment modifies the defined term relating to education and training in subsection (b) of the section. It includes education and training for patients and families, and repeals the role of corporations with respect to fellowships. SEC. 4. MODIFICATION OF REQUIREMENTS FOR BOARDS OF DIRECTORS OF CORPORATIONS. Requirements for Department Board Members under section 7363(a) of title 38, United States Code, are amended to include the director, chief of staff, associate chief of staff for research, and associate chief of staff for education at Department medical centers. If these positions do not exist, the responsible official or officials will carry out the duties. Requirements for Non-Department Board Members are amended to include at least two members with backgrounds in business, legal, financial, medical, or scientific expertise beneficial to the corporation's operations. Conflicts of interest are addressed by prohibiting individuals who are employed by the corporation. SEC. 5. CLARIFICATION OF POWERS OF CORPORATIONS. Section 7364 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to give a corporation established under this subchapter the power to accept and manage funds, enter into contracts, set fees for education and training, and reimburse amounts to the Department's Office of General Counsel. The corporation established under this subchapter has the power to manage funds, enter contracts, set fees for education and training, and reimburse the Department's Office of General Counsel for legal services provided. Fees for education and training for Department officers or employees cannot be paid with Department funds. Amounts reimbursed to the Office of General Counsel are for staff, training, and related travel for legal services and have no fiscal year limitation. The Secretary can transfer funds for research or education at Department medical centers to a corporation for administration. Medical centers can reimburse the corporation for employee expenses and retain funds provided by the corporation. The funds credited to the Department's appropriation account are available without fiscal year limitation for the account's purposes. A corporation established under this subchapter must follow procedures for project approval and spending, including a scientific review process for research projects and approval for education activities. The Under Secretary for Health may prescribe policies and procedures for corporations established under this subchapter to guide fund spending in accordance with laws and regulations. Section 7362(a) of the title is amended by removing the last sentence. Section 7364A of title 38, United States Code, is redesignated as section 7365. The table of sections in chapter 73 is updated accordingly. Additionally, improved accountability and oversight of corporations is emphasized. Each corporation must submit an annual report detailing their operations and accomplishments. Corporations with revenues over $300,000 need an annual audit, while those with revenues between $10,000 and $300,000 require an audit every three years. The report to the Secretary must include the most recent audit and IRS Form 990. The IRS Form 990 and applicable schedules must be submitted annually by each corporation. Conflict of interest regulations apply to officers, directors, and employees, verifying their compliance. The IRS Form 990 must be submitted annually by corporations, with conflict of interest regulations applying to officers, directors, and employees. Amendments include changing the reporting threshold from $35,000 to $50,000.
